extendedMetadata.value: LO: 10.3: What were the arguments for and against the Bank of the United States?,

subject: US History
metadata.bookAuthor: H. W. Brands; T. H. Breen; R. Hal Williams; Ariela J. Gros
metadata.title: FA Analyze 10 02

config.question: Which of the following incidents was most important in preventing the rechartering of the Bank of the United States?

choices.content: the personal feud between Jackson and Calhoun
the issue of South Carolina’s nullification ordinance

answer_3.response: Consider This: The bank sought recharter by Congress in 1832, four years ahead of schedule. The destruction of the Bank and the ensuing economic disruption highlighted the issue of the government’s relationship to the nation’s financial system. Differences on this question strengthened the new two-party system. See L.O. 10.3 What were the arguments for and against the Bank of the United States?
